FUNCTION: Voltage-gated potassium channel inhibitor. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:23148443}.

Organism: Phormingochilus everetti (Malaysian purple earth tiger tarantula)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Ion channel impairing toxin that inhibits several voltage-gated sodium channels. It acts by inhibiting the inward component of the sodium current and by shifting the voltage dependence of channel activation to more depolarized potentials (PubMed:32511987). Its most potent activity is on Nav1.7/SCN9A (IC(50)=167 nM), followed by Nav1.6/SCN8A (IC(50)=696 nM), and Nav1.2/SCN2A (IC(50)=3.54 uM) (PubMed:32511987). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:32511987}.

Organism: Poecilotheria metallica (Metallic blue ornamental tree spider)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Gating-modifier toxin with weak activity on Nav1.7/SCN9A and Nav1.8/SCN10A (PubMed:32092883). Inhibits Nav1.7/SCN9A peak current (IC(50)=334 nM) and shifts the voltage dependence of activation to more depolarised membrane potentials (PubMed:32092883). Shows 21% peak current inhibition (at 10 uM) on Nav1.8/SCN10A sodium channels (PubMed:32092883). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:32092883}.

FUNCTION: Potent and selective inhibitor of Nav1.7/SCN9A sodium channels. Inhibits Nav1.7/SCN9A peak current (IC(50)=13 nM) (PubMed:31647222). In vivo, does not induce visible signs of toxicity when intravenously injected into mice (PubMed:31647222). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:31647222}.

FUNCTION: Gating-modifier toxin that inhibits both sodium (Nav) and calcium (Cav3) channels by inducing hyperpolarizing shift in voltage-dependence of activation and steady state inactivation. Inhibits Nav1.1/SCN1A, Nav1.2/SCN2A, Nav1.3/SCN3A, Nav1.6/SCN6A, Nav1.7/SCN9A and Cav3.1/CACNA1G sodium and calcium channels at nanomolar concentrations (IC(50)=81-301 nM). Surprisingly, selectively slows fast inactivation of Nav1.3/SCN3A. Also shows moderate inhibition of Cav3.2/CACNA1H calcium channels (IC(50)=1233 nM). Ex vivo, nearly ablates neuronal mechanosensitivity in afferent fibers innervating the colon and the bladder. In vivo, in a mouse model of irritable bowel syndrome, intracolonic administration of the toxin reverses colonic mechanical hypersensitivity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:32826759}.

FUNCTION: Gating-modifier toxin that inhibits both sodium (Nav) and calcium (Cav3) channels by inducing hyperpolarizing shift in voltage-dependence of activation and steady state inactivation. Inhibits Nav1.1/SCN1A, Nav1.2/SCN2A, Nav1.6/SCN6A, Nav1.7/SCN9A and Cav3.1/CACNA1G sodium and calcium channels at nanomolar concentrations (IC(50)=169-621 nM). Surprisingly, selectively slows fast inactivation of Nav1.3/SCN3A. Also shows moderate inhibition of Nav1.3/SCN3A sodium channels (IC(50)=1216 nM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:32826759}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them.

FUNCTION: Peptide with both antimicrobial and neurotoxin activities. Cationic AMP with antimicrobial activity against both Gram-positive bacteria (B.subtilis) and Gram-negative bacteria (E.coli and S.enterica). Shows no significant antimicrobial activity against bacteria S.aureus and P.aeruginosa, as well as the fungus C.albicans. In vivo, induces reversible paralytic activity towards the shrimp P.paucidens. May act by impairing sodium or potassium channels in the prey. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A0A1X9QHL1}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:X1WB75}.

Organism: Metridium senile (Brown sea anemone) (Frilled sea anemone)

FUNCTION: Beta toxins bind voltage-independently at site-4 of sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward more negative potentials thereby affecting sodium channel activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing (By similarity). FUNCTION: Delta-conotoxins bind to site 6 of voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and inhibit the inactivation process. Potent paralytic toxin in vertebrate and invertebrate systems. Its binding appears to be voltage-dependent.

FUNCTION: Inhibitor of voltage-gated potassium channels. Inhibits Kv2.1/KCNB1 channels, by shifting activation of the channel to more depolarized voltages. The toxin binding sites may be situated on the S3-S4 extracellular linker of the channel. One, two, three or four toxin molecules may bind the Kv2.1/KCNB1 channel. May need to partition into the membrane in order to bind to the channel. Antibacterial activity is not observed.

FUNCTION: Beta toxins bind voltage-independently at site-4 of sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward more negative potentials thereby affecting sodium channel activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing. Moderately toxic, but very high abundant. Does not target reptilian channels. Does not produce effect when administered to blowfly and cabbage looper larvae. In mice, produces convulsions, tremors, increased ventilation and, subsequently, death. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12423335}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This toxin binds with high affinity to both fetal (alpha-1/beta-1/epsilon/delta subunits) and adult (alpha-1/beta-1/gamma/delta subunits) mammalian muscle nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR).

FUNCTION: Binds and inhibits voltage-sensitive potassium channels. Inhibits the vertebrate potassium channel Kv1.1/KCNA1 with low affinity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14561751}.

Protein names: Chlorotoxin-like peptide MeuClTx (Chloride channel toxin-like peptide)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Inhibits Kv1.2/KCNA2 potassium channels. On glioma cells, may interact with chloride channels (probably Clc-3/CLCN3) and MMP2 at the surface of glioma cells. FUNCTION: Neurotoxin with probable activity on sodium channel. Induces intense repetitive firing of the frog neuromuscular junction, leading to a tetanic contracture in muscle fiber (spastic paralysis). In vivo, shows the same effect as the whole venom when injected on fish prey. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0C829}.

FUNCTION: Delta-conotoxins bind to site 6 of voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and inhibit the inactivation process. This toxin inhibits tetrodotoxin(TTX)-sensitive sodium channels. A test on mouse Nav1.6/SCN8A confirms this sensitivity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25848010}.
FUNCTION: Dual-function toxin that inhibits both the serine protease trypsin and voltage-gated potassium channels (Kv). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:B1B5I8}.

FUNCTION: Potently and selectively inhibits voltage-gated potassium channels Kv11/KCNH/ERG. Acts as a gating-modifier toxin that shifts the voltage-dependence of ERG activation in the positive direction and suppresses its current amplitudes elicited by strong depolarizing pulses that maximally activate the channels. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P61541}.

FUNCTION: Binds specifically to voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and delays their inactivation during signal transduction (when tested on the soma membrane of a crustacean neuron). Has also been observed to affect the activation of the sodium current. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P01533}.

Protein names: U-actitoxin-Avd13a/b (U-AITX-Avd13a/b) (Peptide toxin AV-1) [Cleaved into: U-actitoxin-Avd13b (U-AITX-Avd13b) (AnmTX Avi 9a-1); U-actitoxin-Avd13a (U-AITX-Avd13a) (AnmTX Avi 9a-2)]
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Inhibits ion channels. {ECO:0000305}.
FUNCTION: Inhibits ion channels. {ECO:0000305}.

Organism: Phormingochilus everetti (Malaysian purple earth tiger tarantula)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Ion channel impairing toxin that inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels. The recombinantly expressed toxin shows a weak activity against Nav1.7/SCN9A (25% inhibition at 10 uM), and shifts the voltage dependence of channel activation to more depolarized potentials. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:32511987}.

FUNCTION: Neurotoxin certainly responsible of defensive persistent and painful stings of the giant stinging tree, since it provokes similar effects (PubMed:32938666). Acts by potently delaying voltage-gated sodium channel (Nav) inactivation in a concentration-dependent manner (EC(50)=4 nM) (PubMed:32938666). Mainly targets Nav1.7/SCN9A channels, since the two Nav1.7/SCN9A inhibitors tetrodotoxin and the spider toxin Pn3a potently reduce nocifensive behaviors it causes (By similarity). On the Nav1.7/SCN9A channel, this toxin causes a significant hyperpolarizing shift in the voltage dependence of activation, but has no significant effect on the voltage dependence of steady-state fast inactivation (PubMed:32938666). Its effects on Nav currents are irreversible, with no apparent reduction in activity even after repeated wash steps over 30 minutes (By similarity). In vivo, it causes nocifensive behavior in mice (licking or biting and shaking or lifting of the affected paw) lasting for approximately 1 hour (PubMed:32938666). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DQP3, ECO:0000269|PubMed:32938666}.

FUNCTION: Ion channel inhibitor that inhibits the increase in intracellular calcium upon depolarization in DRG neurons. In vivo, both intraperitoneal and intracranial injections into mice induce hyperactivity. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q5K0C7}.

FUNCTION: Ion channel inhibitor that inhibits the increase in intracellular calcium upon depolarization in DRG neurons. In vivo, both intraperitoneal and intracranial injections into mice induce hyperactivity. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q5K0C7}.

FUNCTION: Binds specifically to voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav), thereby delaying their inactivation. This toxin is active on a variety of voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav1.1/SCN1A, Nav1.2/SCN2A, Nav1.3/SCN3A, Nav1.4/SCN4A, Nav1.5/SCN5A and Nav1.6/SCN8A). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P10454}.

Organism: Crotalus oreganus concolor (Midget faded rattlesnake) (Crotalus viridis concolor)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Cationic peptide that possesses multiple functions. It acts as a cell-penetrating peptide (CPP), and as a potent voltage-gated potassium channel (Kv) inhibitor. It exhibits antimicrobial activities, hind limb paralysis, and severe muscle necrosis by a non-enzymatic mechanism. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9PWF3}.
FUNCTION: Delta-conotoxins bind to site 6 of voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and inhibit the inactivation process. Induces membrane depolarization and spontaneous repetitive firing of neurons.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This globular toxin inhibits mammalian alpha-7/CHRNA7 (IC(50)=0.3-10.1 nM), rat alpha-3-beta-2/CHRNA3-CHRNB2 (IC(50)=10.3 nM) and rat alpha-3-alpha-5-beta-2/CHRNA3-CHRNB5-CHRNB2 (IC(50)=31.2 nM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23924607, ECO:0000269|PubMed:34753970}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and inhibit them. This peptide potently blocks muscular nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND), and has no effect on neuronal receptors. It is able to totally displace [125I]-Bgtx from the Torpedo receptor with an inhibition constant (Ki) of 2.2 and 0.7 nM. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28238803}.

FUNCTION: Neurotoxin that induces paralysis when injected into crabs (By similarity). May function in antimicrobial activity as it displays inhibitory activity towards the B.licheniformis enzyme subtilisin A (SUBTA) and the recombinant S.maltophilia protease 1 (rStmPr1) enzyme (Ref.1). Also displays inhibitory activity against various proteases including the porcine pancreatic elastase (PPE) and proteinase K (PK) (Ref.1). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:C0HK75, ECO:0000269|Ref.1}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This toxin selectively inhibits nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) alpha-3-beta-2 subtype (IC(50)=845.5 nM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26511093}.

Protein names: Alpha-conotoxin Mr1.7a (Conotoxin Mr1.8) [Cleaved into: Alpha-conotoxin MrIC (Mr1.7c); Alpha-conotoxin Mr1.7b (Mr002)]
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: [Alpha-conotoxin MrIC]: Acts as a co-agonist with PNU (an alpha-7 nAChR-selective allosteric modulator) at the endogenous alpha-7/CHRNA7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) when tested in mammalian SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells. Is the third alpha-conotoxin that acts as an agonist (after alpha-conotoxin SrIA/SrIB). Also acts as an antagonist at mammalian alpha-7 nAChRs heterologously expressed in Xenopus oocytes (PubMed:24351107). Has possibly a distinct nAChR binding mode from other alpha-conotoxins, due to a different three residue motif (lacks the Ser-Xaa-Pro motif) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q2I2R8, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24351107}.; FUNCTION: [Alpha-conotoxin Mr1.7a]: Acts as a weak partial agonist at alpha-7/CHRNA7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) when tested in mammalian SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (PubMed:24351107). Has possibly a distinct nAChR binding mode from other alpha-conotoxins, due to a different three residue motif (lacks the Ser-Xaa-Pro motif) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q2I2R8, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24351107}.

FUNCTION: Its target is unknown, but this toxin may modulate voltage-activated calcium channels (Cav) or calcium-dependent potassium channels (KCa). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0C248, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0C250, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P62903, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P83047}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them (By similarity). This toxin also inhibits high voltage-activated (HVA) calcium channel currents in rat DRG neurons (8% inhibition at 1 uM toxin) probably by activating GABA(B) receptors (GABBR1 and/or GABBR2) (PubMed:26948522). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0CE73, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26948522}.

Organism: Conus milneedwardsi (Glory of India cone snail)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This toxin inhibits muscle nAChRs with moderate potency (IC(50)=11 uM on alpha-1-beta-1-delta-epsilon/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRND-CHRNE (adult), and IC(50)=13 uM on alpha-1-beta-1-gamma-delta/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND (fetal)). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:31527432}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This toxin inhibits fetal and adult muscle-type nAChR (IC(50)=52.1 nM towards alpha-1-beta-1-gamma-delta/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND, and IC(50)=102.8 nM towards alpha-1-beta-1-delta-epsilon/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRND-CHRNE). Shows potent activity on the synthetic AChR alpha-1-beta-1-delta/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRND (IC(50)=16.9 nM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:36292948}.

Protein names: Phospholipase A2 homolog mojave toxin acidic chain (Mtx-a) [Cleaved into: Mojave toxin acidic chain A; Mojave toxin acidic chain B; Mojave toxin acidic chain C]
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Snake venom phospholipase A2 (PLA2) that inhibits neuromuscular transmission by blocking acetylcholine release from the nerve termini.

FUNCTION: Chi-conotoxins inhibit the neuronal noradrenaline transporter (NET/SLC6A2) (By similarity). Induces flaccid paralysis, when injected intra-cerebroventricularly into mice. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P58808, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10988292}.
FUNCTION: Lethal neurotoxin that blocks neuromuscular transmission. Acts cooperatively to potentiate the activity of huwentoxin-I. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10424342}.

FUNCTION: Iota-conotoxins bind to voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and act as agonists by shifting the voltage-dependence of activation to more hyperpolarized levels (By similarity). Both natural (L-Thr form) and synthetic (D-Thr form) peptides cause paralysis and death following intracranial injection and grooming and hypersensitivity upon intraperitoneal injection into mice. The L-Thr form of the peptide is 7-fold more potent than the D-Thr form. Both natural peptide (L-Thr form) and synthetic peptide (D-Thr form) are active on nerve, and on muscle. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17996262}.

FUNCTION: Iota-conotoxins bind to voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and act as agonists by shifting the voltage-dependence of activation to more hyperpolarized levels (By similarity). Produces excitatory symptoms when injected intracranially into mice and is lethal at higher doses. Exposure to frog cutaneous pectoris induces spontaneous and repetitive action potentials. This effect is slowly reversible. Natural peptide (with D-Phe) is active on nerve, but not on muscle. Synthetic peptide (with L-Phe) is not active on both nerve and muscle. {ECO:0000250}.

FUNCTION: Iota-conotoxins bind to voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and act as agonists by shifting the voltage-dependence of activation to more hyperpolarized levels (By similarity). Causes circular motion, convulsions, copious urination, rigid paralysis and death upon intracranial injection into mice. Causes unbalanced swimming, swimming in diagonal and vertical motion and death, when injected intraperitoneally into goldfish. L-Leu and D-Leu forms are active on both nerve and muscle. {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P69747}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:E2DIH5}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0CE73}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:E2DIH5}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:E2DIH5}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them (PubMed:31255696). This toxin potently and selectively inhibits mammalian and rat alpha-6-beta-4/CHRNA6-CHRNB4 nAChR (IC(50)=12 nM on rat nAChR) (PubMed:31255696). It exhibits rapid binding and unbinding at this receptor (PubMed:31255696). It also shows activity on rat alpha-6-beta-4/CHRNA6-CHRNB4 (IC(50)=12 nM), mammalian alpha-6/alpha-3-beta-4 (CHRNA6/CHRNA3-CHRNB4) (IC(50)=5.3 nM), rat alpha-6/alpha-3-beta-4 (CHRNA6/CHRNA3-CHRNB4) (IC(50)=18 nM), rat alpha-3-beta-4/CHRNA3-CHRNB4 (IC(50)=320 nM), and rat alpha-6/alpha-3-beta-2-beta-3 (CHRNA6/CHRNA3-CHRNB2-CHRNB3) (IC(50)=4 uM) (PubMed:31255696). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:31255696}.
FUNCTION: Sodium channel inhibitor. 5 uM completely inhibits voltage-gated sodium channel (Nav) inactivation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19609479}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and inhibit them. This peptide potently blocks muscular nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND), and has no effect on neuronal receptors. It is able to totally displace [125I]-Bgtx from the Torpedo receptor with a complete inhibition in the high micromolar range. It produces a biphasic inhibition curve which fits nicely with a two-site model (Ki of 0.46 and 105 nM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23584713}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. Shows inhibition on alpha-3-beta-2/CHRNA3-CHRNB2 (IC(50)=75 nM), alpha-7/CHRNA7 (IC(50)=637 nM) and alpha-9-alpha-10/CHRNA9-CHRNA10 nAChRs (IC(50)=1000 nM). In addition, it also shows inhibition on high-voltage activated (HVA) calcium channels currents (30% at 100 nM) that are mediated by GABA(B) receptors (GABBR1 and GABBR2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21504902}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This toxin weakly inhibits alpha-9-alpha-10/CHRNA9-CHRNA10 nAChRs (IC(50)=3 uM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28666820}.

FUNCTION: Gamma-conotoxins may act on voltage-gated non-specific cation pacemaker channels (HCN) (By similarity). Elicits toxic effects in the freshwater snail Pomacea paludosa after intramuscular injection, but it has no effect when injected intracerebrally into mice. {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Gamma-conotoxins may act on voltage-gated non-specific cation pacemaker channels (HCN). {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Intrathorax injection into crickets causes paralysis prolonged for more than 60 min, followed by recovery. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15246762}.
FUNCTION: Intrathorax injection into crickets causes death. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15246762}.

FUNCTION: This toxin activates voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav1.3/SCN3A (EC(50)=3.98 nM), Nav1.4/SCN4A (EC(50)=4.99 nM), Nav1.6/SCN8A (EC(50)=1.27 nM) and Nav1.7/SCN9A (EC(50)=2.42 nM)). It shifts the voltage-dependence of activation to more hyperpolarized potentials but has only little effect on channel inactivation. In vivo, it induces nocifensive or pain-like behaviors in mice when injected intraplantarly. This is coherent with the specific defensive role deduced from its proximal position in the venom gland. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26156767}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250}.

FUNCTION: Probable competitive antagonist of fish muscle acetylcholine receptor. Inhibits postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) from fish (zebrafish and goldfish) and frogs (IC(50)=0.1 uM). Protects these receptors from block by alpha-bungarotoxin and alpha-conotoxin EI. Does not block nAChRs at the neuromuscular junction of Rana pipiens. Shows a weak inhibition on mammalian adult and fetal muscle nAChRs (alpha-1-beta-1-delta-epsilon/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRND-CHRNE and alpha-1 beta-1 gamma delta/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND) (IC(50)=3-45 uM). In vivo, induces paralysis in goldfish (Carassius auratus) but not mice. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:32245200}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and inhibit them. This toxin selectively inhibits alpha-3-beta-2/CHRNA3-CHRNB2 (IC(50)=3.51 uM) and alpha-6/alpha-3-beta-2-beta-3 (CHRNA6/CHRNA3-CHRNB2-CHRNB3) (IC(50)=0.94 uM) nAChRs. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:33801301}.

Protein names: Kunitz-like toxin PcKuz1 (Kunitz-type serine protease inhibitor PcKuz1) (PI-sphenopitoxin-Pc1a) (PI-SPTX-Pc1a)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Weak serine protease inhibitor that has been tested on both trypsin and elastase (PubMed:29285938). May also act as a neurotoxin by inhibiting voltage-gated potassium channels (Kv) (By similarity). In vivo, is lethal to zebrafish larvae (PubMed:29285938). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P00980, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DQT3, ECO:0000269|PubMed:29285938}.

FUNCTION: Slowly and reversibly inhibits mammalian nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) alpha-7/CHRNA7 (IC(50)=45.7 uM). It is unknown whether it inhibits nAChRs by a competitive or a non-competitive mechanism. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:35307452}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. Is active on muscle nAChR. On mice muscle receptors, its higher affinity site is the alpha/delta nAChR subunit interface. On Torpedo receptors, it does not distinguish between alpha/delta and alpha/gamma acetylcholine-binding sites. In vivo, causes paralysis followed by death when injected into goldfish. In contrast, has no effect on mice, when similar doses are intraperitoneally or intracerebrally injected. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P15471}.

FUNCTION: Probable neurotoxin with unknown target (Probable). Possibly targets ion channels (Probable). In vivo, intraperitoneal injection into fish provokes paralysis after 5 minutes (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0CH15, ECO:0000305}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and inhibit them. This synthetic peptide inhibits rat alpha-6/alpha-3-beta-4 nAChR (IC(50)=3.3 uM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:36682014}.
FUNCTION: Neurotoxin. Causes spastic paralysis and death in mice within 10 minutes at dose levels of 3 ug per mouse. {ECO:0000269|Ref.2, ECO:0000305}.

FUNCTION: Inhibits Kv11.1/KCNH2/ERG1, Kv1.1/KCNA1, Kv1.2/KCNA2 voltage-gated potassium channels and Nav1.7/SCN9A voltage-gated sodium channels (PubMed:29483648). In vivo, no toxicity is observed upon intracranial injection into mice and intrathorax injection into crickets. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15246762, ECO:0000269|PubMed:29483648}.
FUNCTION: Intrathorax injection into crickets causes paralysis prolonged for more than 60 min, followed by recovery. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15246762}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. Globular isomer (C1-C3; C2-C4) selectively inhibits neuronal (non-muscle) nAChR subtypes particularly mammalian alpha-3-beta-2/CHRNA3-CHRNB2 (IC(50)=35.7 nM) and alpha-9-alpha-10/CHRNA9-CHRNA10 nAChRs (IC(50)=569 nM), while the ribbon isomer (C1-C4; C2-C3) shows weak inhibition on alpha-3-beta-2/CHRNA3-CHRNB2, but not on all other receptors tested. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34062129}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. Both the globular (with C1-C3; C2-C4 disulfide pattern) and ribbon (C1-C4; C2-C3) isomers reversibly inhibit mammalian muscle-type alpha-1-beta-1-delta-epsilon/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRND-CHRNE nAChRs (IC(50)=116 nM and IC(50)=643 nM, respectively) (PubMed:34062129). Both isomers also inhibit alpha-7/CHRNA7 and alpha-9-alpha-10/CHRNA9-CHRNA10 (IC(50)=1113 nM by globular isomer) nAChRs (PubMed:34062129). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34062129}.

FUNCTION: This toxin activates voltage-gated sodium channels. It shifts the voltage-dependence of activation to more hyperpolarized potentials but has only little effect on channel inactivation. It is active on Nav1.3/SCN3A (EC(50)=3.98 nM), Nav1.4/SCN4A (EC(50)=4.99 nM), Nav1.6/SCN8A (EC(50)=1.27 nM) and Nav1.7/SCN9A (EC(50)=2.42 nM) voltage-gated sodium channels. In vivo, it induces nocifensive or pain-like behaviors in mice when injected intraplantarly. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DL67}.

Organism: Terebra guttata (White spotted auger snail) (Epitonium guttatum)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: The recombinant protein causes paralysis to polychaete worms (Nereis virens), the natural prey of terebrid snails. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26950153}.

FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. This toxin inhibits alpha-3-beta-4, alpha-6/alpha-3-beta-4, and alpha-2-beta-4 nAChRs. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:K8DWB5}.
FUNCTION: Binds to sodium channels (Nav) and affects the channel activation process. {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Binds to sodium channels (Nav) and affects the channel activation process. {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Binds the voltage-sensor domain of the potassium channel KvAP (from the archaeon Aeropyrum pernix) and affects channel gating. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15287735}.

FUNCTION: Iota-conotoxins bind to voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav) and act as agonists by shifting the voltage-dependence of activation to more hyperpolarized levels. Produces general excitatory symptoms (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Alpha-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, they bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) and thus inhibit them. {ECO:0000250}.
FUNCTION: Intracerebroventricular injection paralyzes mice. Has no effect on voltage-gated sodium currents.
FUNCTION: Intracisternal injection paralyzes mice.

Protein names:
RecName: Full=U1-theraphotoxin-Tal1a; Short=U1-TRTX-Tal1a; AltName:
Full=Brachyin; Flags: Precursor.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Insecticidal toxin that shows strong lethal effects on
            American cockroaches (P.americana) and common mealbeetle
            (T.molitor) (PubMed:25329070). Possibly acts by blocking ion
            channel currents (Probable). Also shows significant analgesic
            effects in mice models of pain including abdominal writhing induced
            by acetic acid and formalin-induced paw licking tests
            (PubMed:25329070). In addition, exerts marked inhibition of
            proliferation of some mammalian tumor cell lines including C8166,
            Molt-4, A-549, BIU-87, T24, and Calu-6 (PubMed:25329070).
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070, ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:25329070}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4901.7; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 5 ug/kg in adult cockroaches.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 7.6 ug/kg in mealbeetles.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 14 (magi-1) family. 08
            (Ltx-4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] This toxin shifts the voltage-dependence of Nav1.4/SCN4A
            activation to more hyperpolarised potentials, inhibits
            inactivation, and produces large ramp currents, consistent with its
            profound effects on contractile force in an isolated skeletal
            muscle preparation (PubMed:27763551). This toxin produces large
            muscle contractions and fasciculations in the indirectly stimulated
            chick biventer cervicis nerve-muscle assay, which are significantly
            inhibited by the addition of the sodium channel antagonist
            tetrodotoxin (PubMed:27763551). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27763551}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27763551}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:27763551}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=6725.9; Method=Electrospray;
            Note=Monoisotopic mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:27763551}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Beta toxins bind voltage-independently at site-4 of
            sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward
            more negative potentials thereby affecting sodium channel
            activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P60266}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23840487}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:23840487}.
            [DOMAIN] Has the structural arrangement of an alpha-helix connected
            to antiparallel beta-sheets by disulfide bonds (CS-alpha/beta).
            {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=6814; Method=Electrospray; Note=Average
            mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:23840487}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the long (4 C-C) scorpion toxin
            superfamily. Sodium channel inhibitor family. Beta subfamily.
            {ECO:0000255}.

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Alpha-elapitoxin-Lc2c; Short=Alpha-EPTX-Lc2c;
AltName: Full=Long neurotoxin 1.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Binds with high affinity to muscular nicotinic
            acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs), whereas it binds with a low
            affinity to neuronal alpha-7/CHRNA7 nAChRs.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305882}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Has the length of long neurotoxins, but only 4
            disulfide bonds instead of the 5 usually present in long
            neurotoxins. This may explain why this toxin has the low affinity
            to alpha-7 nAChRs of short neurotoxins, which have only 4 disulfide
            bonds.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Long-chain subfamily. Type II alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Short neurotoxin 1/5; Short=SNTX1; Short=SNTX5;
AltName: Full=Alpha-neurotoxin 1/5; Flags: Precursor.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Binds with high affinity to muscle nicotinic
            acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) and inhibit acetylcholine from
            binding to the receptor, thereby impairing neuromuscular
            transmission. Compete with the binding of alpha-bungarotoxin on
            muscle AChR (from Torpedo) with an IC(50) of 0.31 uM (SNTX1) and
            3.1 uM (SNTX5). Is able of exerting muscle paralysis, spasms and
            increased respiration. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10518793}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250}.
            [ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS] Event=Alternative splicing; Named
            isoforms=2; Name=SNTX1; IsoId=Q9W7K2-1; Sequence=Displayed;
            Name=SNTX5; IsoId=Q9W7K2-2; Sequence=VSP_006534.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 1 mg/kg by intravenous injection into mice.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10518793}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Type III alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Binds with high affinity to muscle nicotinic
            acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) and hinders acetylcholine binding to

            Competes with the binding of alpha-bungarotoxin on muscle AChR
            (from Torpedo) with an IC(50) of 0.30 uM. Causes muscle paralysis,
            spasms and increased respiration. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10518793}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16284125}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:16284125}.

            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Type III alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Binds with high affinity to muscular
            (alpha-1-beta-1-gamma-delta/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND) and neuronal
            (alpha-7/CHRNA7) nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) and
            inhibits acetylcholine from binding to the receptor, thereby
            impairing neuromuscular and neuronal transmission
            (PubMed:33672715). Ranges of nAChR inhibition are in nanomolar
            (competitive binding with alpha-bungarotoxin gives Ki=1.66 nM on
            muscle nAChR and Ki=4.84 nM on alpha-7) (PubMed:33672715). Also
            shows moderate inhibition on GABA(A) alpha-1-beta-3-gamma-2
            receptor (GABRA1-GABRB3-GABRG2) (IC(50)=0.68 uM), and a lower
            inhibition on alpha-1-beta-2-gamma-2 (GABRA1-GABRB2-GABRG2) and
            alpha-3-beta-2-gamma-2 (GABRA3-GABRB2-GABRG2) (PubMed:33672715).
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:33672715}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:33672715}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:33672715}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=7787.58; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:33672715}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Long-chain subfamily. Type II alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Binds with high affinity to muscular
            (alpha-1-beta-1-gamma-delta/CHRNA1-CHRNB1-CHRNG-CHRND) and neuronal
            (alpha-7/CHRNA7) nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) and
            inhibits acetylcholine from binding to the receptor, thereby
            impairing neuromuscular and neuronal transmission
            (PubMed:33672715). Ranges of nAChR inhibition are in nanomolar
            (competitive binding with alpha-bungarotoxin gives Ki=8.66 nM on
            muscle nAChR and Ki=9.47 nM on alpha-7) (PubMed:33672715). Also

            inhibition on alpha-1-beta-2-gamma-2 (GABRA1-GABRB2-GABRG2) and
            alpha-3-beta-2-gamma-2 (GABRA3-GABRB2-GABRG2) (PubMed:33672715).

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Cobrotoxin-b; Short=CBT-b; AltName: Full=Short
neurotoxin III; Short=NT3.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Produces peripheral paralysis by blocking neuromuscular
            transmission at the postsynaptic site. Binds to the nicotinic
            acetylcholine receptor. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12039691,
            ECO:0000305|PubMed:12039691}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12039691}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 400 mg/kg by intraperitoneal injection into
            mice. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12039691}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] It inhibits muscle contraction with an IC(50) of
            0.23 ug/ml. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11904231}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Type I alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Produces peripheral paralysis by blocking neuromuscular
            transmission at the postsynaptic site. Very weak inhibitor of the
            endogenous nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) in the mammalian
            rhabdomyosarcoma TE 671 cell line. This neurotoxin is lethal to
            zebrafish by injection at the back of the dorsolateral region, but
            is not toxic to mice by intraperitoneal injection.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18384102}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18384102}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Ancestral subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Produces peripheral paralysis by blocking neuromuscular
            transmission at the postsynaptic site. Weak inhibitor of the
            endogenous nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) in the mammalian
            rhabdomyosarcoma TE 671 cell line with an IC(50) of 690 mM. This
            neurotoxin is lethal to zebrafish by injection at the back of the

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Short neurotoxin MS11; AltName: Full=Three-finger
toxin; Short=3FTx.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Produces peripheral paralysis by blocking neuromuscular
            transmission at the postsynaptic site. Binds to and inhibits the
            endogenous nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) in the mammalian
            rhabdomyosarcoma TE 671 cell line with an IC(50) of 266 mM. Not
            toxic to mice by intraperitoneal injection or to zebrafish by
            injection at the back dorsolateral region.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18384102}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18384102}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Produces peripheral paralysis by blocking neuromuscular
            transmission at the postsynaptic site. Very weak inhibitor of the
            endogenous nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) in the mammalian
            rhabdomyosarcoma TE 671 cell line. Not toxic to mice by
            intraperitoneal injection or to zebrafish by injection at the back
            of the dorsolateral region. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18384102}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18384102}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.

            Ancestral subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Mipartoxin-1; AltName: Full=Mipartoxin-I; AltName:
Full=Three-finger toxin; Short=3FTx; Flags: Precursor.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Snake venom neurotoxin that blocks neuromuscular
            transmission on both avian and mouse nerve-muscle preparations,
            presenting a postsynaptic action through the nicotinic
            acetylcholine receptor (nAChR). Reversibly inhibits twitches in
            mouse phrenic nerve diaphragm and irreversibly in chick biventer
            cervicis muscle. Has no cytotoxic activity towards C2C12 cells up
            to 180 ug/ml. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22677806}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22677806}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:31557485}.
            [PTM] Contains 4 disulfide bonds. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22677806}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=7029.7; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:22677806}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=7030.0; Mass_error=0.5;
            Method=Electrospray; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:22677806}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 0.06 mg/kg by intraperitoneal injection into
            mice. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22677806}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Binds to muscle nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR)
            and inhibit acetylcholine from binding to the receptor, thereby
            impairing neuromuscular transmission.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24440452}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24440452}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24440452}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=6982.1; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:24440452}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Type I alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Alpha-elapitoxin-Aa2e; Short=Alpha-EPTX-Aa2e;
AltName: Full=Aa el/Aa e2.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Binds with high affinity to muscular (alpha-1/CHRNA1)
            and neuronal (alpha-7/CHRNA7) nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
            (nAChR) and inhibits acetylcholine from binding to the receptor,
            thereby impairing neuromuscular and neuronal transmission (By
            similarity). Produces paralysis, clear dyspnea and lethality on
            mice (PubMed:9133710). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P60615,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133710}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133710}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=8752.02; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133710}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is between 0.05 and 0.20 mg/kg by
            intraperitoneal injection into mice. These data should be viewed
            cautiously since only a few mice have been injected due to the low
            amount of toxin available. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9133710}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Exists in two forms which are separated by
            reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography, but which
            have the same sequence and molecular weight. The existence of cis
            and trans isomers may explain the two different elution peaks
            (PubMed:9133710). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:9133710}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Long-chain subfamily. Type II alpha-neurotoxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Binds weakly to the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor
            (CHRM) (By similarity). Does not show inhibition on GABA(A)
            receptors (PubMed:33672715). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P82462,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:33672715}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P82462}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P82462}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P82462}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=7441.50; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:33672715}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Is classified as a P-type cytotoxin, since a
            proline residue stands at position 33 (Pro-31 in standard
            classification). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P82462}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Type C muscarinic toxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.
            [CAUTION] Has been partially sequenced. The missing C-terminal
            residues are assumed to be the same as in the orthologs and are
            therefore indicated in the sequence. {ECO:0000305}.

Protein names: RecName: Full=Muscarinic toxin BM14; Flags: Precursor.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] This toxin inhibits the binding of [3H]quinuclidinyl
            benzilate to the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine (mAchR) receptor
            subtype (CHRM2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=9075; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not bind to receptor M1
            (CHRM1). Is unable to compete with alpha-bungarotoxin for binding
            to nAchR at concentrations up to 100 uM. Does not manifest
            cytotoxicity toward myelogenous leukemia cells. Is not toxic to
            mice at doses up to 3 mg/kg. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Ancestral subfamily. Orphan group XVII sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Blocks M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (CHRM2).
            Fully blocks the binding of N-methylscopolamine (NMS) and
            oxotremorine-M to M2 receptors, slightly increased NMS binding to
            M1 receptors. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10531397}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000303|PubMed:10531397}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10531397}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: has no effect on M3, M4 and M5
            muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10531397}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Type B muscarinic toxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Binds irreversibly and specifically to M1 (CHRM1)

Protein names: RecName: Full=Toxin BMLCL; AltName: Full=BM8; Flags: Precursor.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Interacts with high efficiency with both neuronal
            alpha-7/CHRNA7 and muscle type nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
            (nAChRs). Tested on mammalian alpha-7/CHRNA7 nAChR (IC(50)=42 nM),
            T.californica muscle receptor (IC(50)=31 nM), L.stagnalis and
            A.californica acetylcholine-binding proteins (IC(50)=333 nM and 3.4
            uM, respectively). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26518551}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:12437132}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=9019; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not bind to muscarinic
            acetylcholine receptors M1 and M2 (CHRM1/CHRM2). Is unable to
            compete with alpha-bungarotoxin for binding to nAchR at
            concentrations up to 100 uM. Is not toxic to mice at doses up to 3
            mg/kg. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12437132}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Ancestral subfamily. Orphan group XVII sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Antagonist of muscle and neuronal nicotinic
            acetylcholine receptors (nAChR) with highest affinity for neuronal
            alpha-7/CHRNA7 nAChRs. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A8N286}.
            [SUBUNIT] Homodimer; non-covalently linked.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:A8N286}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11082188}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=7615; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11082188}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Orphan group VIII (haditoxin) sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

[FUNCTION] Highly potent on various alpha-adrenoceptors (ADRA)
            (subnanomolar affinity for ADRA1A). Order of potency is the
            following: ADRA1A (Ki=0.37 nM) > ADRA1B (Ki=10.47 nM) > ADRA1D
            (Ki=104.71 nM) > ADRA2C (Ki=165.96 nM). Were also found to
            reversibly bind to muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (CHRM), but
            the affinity is much weaker (CHRM1, Ki=1778.28 nM; CHRM4,
            Ki=4466.84 nM; CHRM2, Ki=17782.79 nM).
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23648423}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:4029488}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:4029488}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 56 mg/kg by intravenous injection.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:4029488}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not bind to muscarinic
            receptors CHRM5 and CHRM3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23648423}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Is classified as a P-type cytotoxin, since a
            proline residue stands at position 33 (Pro-31 in standard
            classification). {ECO:0000305}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the snake three-finger toxin family.
            Short-chain subfamily. Aminergic toxin sub-subfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

Protein names:
RecName: Full=Kappa-actitoxin-Ael2e; Short=Kappa-AITX-Ael2e;
AltName: Full=Toxin APETx4.
Function [CC]:
[FUNCTION] Inhibits voltage-gated potassium and sodium channels. It
            potently inhibits mammalian Kv10.1/KCNH1/EAG1 (IC(50)=1.1 uM) and
            Kv1.4/KCNA4, and moderately inhibits rat Kv1.3/KCNA3, mammalian
            Kv1.5/KCNA5 and mammalian Kv2.1/KCNB1. Likely to act as a
            gating-modifier toxin that binds to closed Kv10.1 channels and
            reduces their activation by shifting their voltage-dependence in
            the positive direction and suppressing their current amplitudes
            elicited by strong depolarizing pulses. On sodium channels, it
            blocks rat Nav1.4/SCN4A, mammalian Nav1.5/SCN5A and displays relatively
            weak inhibition of mouse Nav1.6/SCN8A.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28902151}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28902151}.
            Nematocyst {ECO:0000305}.
            [DOMAIN] Has the CSbeta/beta fold, which comprises anti-parallel
            beta-sheets stabilized by three or four disulfide bonds.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P61541}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4651.02; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:28902151}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4651.00; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:28902151}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not block mammalian
            Kv11.1/KCNH2/ERG1, Xenopus laevis Kv11.1/KCNH2/ERG1 and mammalian
            Kv1.1/KCNA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28902151}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the sea anemone type 3 (BDS) potassium
            channel toxin family. {ECO:0000305}.
